    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/journey-to-palmyra-atoll-the-paradise-where-tv-cameras-have-never-been-684824131857</guid>
      <title>Only a Few Dozen Have Visited This Paradise in 15 Years</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 07:00:53 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/journey-to-palmyra-atoll-the-paradise-where-tv-cameras-have-never-been-684824131857</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Palmyra Atoll is located 1,000 miles south of Hawaii. The spectacular marine wilderness is so remote that TV cameras haven't been there — until now.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1535691/2016-05-12t22-58-49-533z-1280x720_3507568e98c92bee189ac08adb384be2.jpg" medium="image" height="720" width="1280">
        <media:credit>NBC News</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: A crab at Palmyra Atoll</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A crab at Palmyra Atoll, a spectacular marine wilderness around 1,000 miles south of Hawaii.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/video/air-pollution-levels-rising-in-world-s-poorest-cities-684630595998</guid>
      <title>Air Pollution Levels Rising In World's Poorest Cities</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 06:20:12 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/video/air-pollution-levels-rising-in-world-s-poorest-cities-684630595998</link>
      <dc:creator>Rebecca Davis</dc:creator>
      <description>A new study released by the World Health Organization finds urban air quality in decline around the globe putting more people than ever at risk of env</description>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/video/oregon-crews-electrofish-to-study-river-life-684972099633</guid>
      <title>Oregon Crews 'Electrofish' to Study River Life</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 04:53:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/video/oregon-crews-electrofish-to-study-river-life-684972099633</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Biologists with the city of Portland, Oregon, shock fish along the Willamette River for study as part of the city's effort to improve the river.</description>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/giant-galapagos-tortoise-has-9-hatchlings-aged-80-n572626</guid>
      <title>World's Oldest Mom? Tortoise, 80, Has Babies With Boy Toy</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 12:05:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/giant-galapagos-tortoise-has-9-hatchlings-aged-80-n572626</link>
      <dc:creator>Andy Eckardt</dc:creator>
      <description>A Swiss senior citizen may have just become the world's oldest mother at the age of 80.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1534006/nigritababy_d25c361e3c645d4fb2767a8969c5935b.jpg" medium="image" height="1936" width="1296">
        <media:credit>Samuel Furrer</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Nigrita the tortoise and one of her babies</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Nigrita the tortoise and one of her babies pictured in Zurich Zoo.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1534006/nigritababy_d25c361e3c645d4fb2767a8969c5935b.jpg" medium="image" height="1936" width="1296">
        <media:credit>Samuel Furrer</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Nigrita the tortoise and one of her babies</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Nigrita the tortoise watches over one of her babies in Zurich Zoo.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1534016/nigritababies_0cc2ed76300af110a4bed4954fc956fe.jpg" medium="image" height="1499" width="2244">
        <media:credit>Samuel Furrer</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Jumbo alongside some of his offspring</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Jumbo enjoys a meal alongside some of his offspring in Zurich Zoo.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://time.com/4326721/air-pollution-poor-cities/</guid>
      <title>80 Percent of Urban Dwellers Live With Unsafe Air Pollution</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 07:57:33 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://time.com/4326721/air-pollution-poor-cities/</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>A World Health Organization report suggests that global urban pollution levels increased by 8 percent in the five years preceding 2013.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533926/160512-air-pollution-0350_6d6dc541bbc02fecebc13a8e05dfeec1.jpg" medium="image" height="2344" width="4160">
        <media:credit>Frank Augstein</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Anti-pollution protest in London on April 27, 2016</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">An anti-pollution protest in London, England, on April 27, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/first-alien-earth-still-elusive-despite-huge-exoplanet-haul-n572386</guid>
      <title>Alien Earth Still Elusive Despite Huge Exoplanet Haul</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 20:33:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/first-alien-earth-still-elusive-despite-huge-exoplanet-haul-n572386</link>
      <dc:creator>Mike Wall, Space.com</dc:creator>
      <description>The first 'alien Earth' continues to evade detection.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533441/160511-exoplanet-kepler-mdl_e654a515f3ce759c21c2b30939a97b25.jpg" medium="image" height="440" width="670">
        <media:credit>NASA Ames/SETI Institute/JPL-Caltech</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Artist's illustration of Kepler-186f, an exoplanet similar in size to Earth that appears to orbit in the habitable zone of its parent star.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/brazilian-researchers-find-evidence-zika-getting-worse-n572186</guid>
      <title>Researchers Find Evidence Zika Is Getting Even Worse</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 17:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/brazilian-researchers-find-evidence-zika-getting-worse-n572186</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Brazilian researchers studying Zika virus say they've found evidence it may have evolved into a new form that's more likely to cause birth defects.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533156/zika-electro_f8ad0b5efa522713354bc8a4b86437f6.jpg" medium="image" height="480" width="512">
        <media:credit>Richard Kuhn, Purdue University</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A cryo-electron microscopy image of the Zika virus structure. The triangle highlights the asymmetric unit of the virus.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1533156/zika-electro_f8ad0b5efa522713354bc8a4b86437f6.jpg" medium="image" height="480" width="512">
        <media:credit>Richard Kuhn, Purdue University</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A cryo-electron microscopy image of the Zika virus structure. The triangle highlights the asymmetric unit of the virus.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/low-tech-trap-might-help-fight-zika-virus-outbreaks-cdc-n571501</guid>
      <title>Low-Tech Trap Might Help Fight Zika Virus Outbreaks</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 08:01:33 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/low-tech-trap-might-help-fight-zika-virus-outbreaks-cdc-n571501</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>A low-tech mosquito trap might help control the mosquitoes that spread Zika virus, as well as other viruses such as dengue and chikungunya.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1531866/cdc_21081_ds5_bd004a969bd2bfa6623a9ef2b2e89696.jpeg" medium="image" height="419" width="600">
        <media:credit></media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">This bucket trap was made by health officials in Puerto Rico. They hope it might help communities fight Zika virus.
Components include a black pail(a), a black pail lid(b), a 12.8cm entrance diameter(c), a black capture surface (CS) coated with adhesive(d), PAM(e), a 9.3 l capacity infusion reservoir(f), and a screen barrier between the CS and the infusion reservoir(g)</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1531881/cdc_21081_ds5_7ef34833f375a688bcffaccb9544ce2a.jpeg" medium="image" height="419" width="600">
        <media:credit>CDC</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">CDC and the Puerto Rico Department of Health designed this simple bucket trap to control Aedes aegypti mosquitoes</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/facelift-bottle-second-skin-tightens-baggy-eyes-protects-dry-skin-n570521</guid>
      <title>Did These Researchers Invent a Facelift in a Bottle?</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:04:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/facelift-bottle-second-skin-tightens-baggy-eyes-protects-dry-skin-n570521</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>It sounds almost too good to be true — a two-step cream that tightens up baggy eyes and that can keep dry legs from flaking.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1529751/160509-second_skin-gonick-cream-mdl_b07089e163e3774cad54b204caf36f04.jpg" medium="image" height="2400" width="3600">
        <media:credit>Melanie Gonick/MIT</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Researchers at MIT have developed a two-step cream that tightens and protects skin, providing a temporary face lift  and perhaps offering new ways to deliver drugs.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/mercury-transit-sun-monday-science-smorgasbord-n570461</guid>
      <title>Mercury Transit of the Sun Is a Science Smorgasbord</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 13:29:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/mercury-transit-sun-monday-science-smorgasbord-n570461</link>
      <dc:creator>Nola Taylor Redd, Space.com</dc:creator>
      <description>Mercury's rare passage across the face of the sun on Monday, May 9, should be an exciting event for skywatchers and scientists alike.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_19/1529811/160509-mercury-transit-mdl_b62ed1cc612812c96f176c63ff50a807.jpg" medium="image" height="1588" width="2500">
        <media:credit>NASA</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">The Mercury transit will occur between about 7:12 a.m. and 2:42 p.m. EDT on May 9, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/mens-health/deep-masculine-voice-not-you-ladies-n569631</guid>
      <title>That Deep, Masculine Voice Is Not For You, Ladies</title>
      <pubDate>Sun, 08 May 2016 15:11:30 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/mens-health/deep-masculine-voice-not-you-ladies-n569631</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Men's deep, resonant voices did not evolve to thrill the ladies, but to scare off their rivals, researchers say.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/555971/140709-gorilla_a967783a93eb02c8d9e59c39a7209beb.jpg" medium="image" height="384" width="575">
        <media:credit>Michelle Klailova</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Makumba</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Males gorillas are twice as big as females, and they tend to have "harems". But do their deep roars thrill the ladies?</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_15/969941/150409-science-mountain_gorilla_family_2541e0300d202de898f8a264dc783816.jpg" medium="image" height="1061" width="1600">
        <media:credit>Gorilla Doctors/UC Davis</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Mountain gorillas</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Roughly 880 critically endangered mountain gorillas live in Rwanda, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. </media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/science/science-news/boaty-mcboatface-rejected-name-new-polar-research-ship-n569171</guid>
      <title>Boaty McBoatface Rejected as Name for Research Ship</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 11:25:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/science/science-news/boaty-mcboatface-rejected-name-new-polar-research-ship-n569171</link>
      <dc:creator>Alexander Smith</dc:creator>
      <description>British officials were branded spoilsports Friday after refusing to name a polar research ship "Boaty McBoatface."</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1526556/160506_-_david_attenborough_-_0602_4eb6fea5a0ab775c2559c76cb91328b4.jpg" medium="image" height="1965" width="3707">
        <media:credit>U.K. Department for Business, Innovation & Skills</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: RRS Sir David Attenborough</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A computer-generated image of the British polar research ship, whose name was announced as the RRS Sir David Attenborough on Friday.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/video/spacex-launches-falcon-9-rocket-lands-successfully-680512067996</guid>
      <title>SpaceX Launches Falcon 9 Rocket, Lands Successfully</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 06:22:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/video/spacex-launches-falcon-9-rocket-lands-successfully-680512067996</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>SpaceX successfully landed the first stage of its Falcon 9 rocket on a ship at sea during a mission to launch a Japanese satellite into orbit.</description>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/spacex-launch-japanese-satellite-try-rocket-landing-n569101</guid>
      <title>SpaceX Successfully Lands Satellite Launch Rocket at Sea</title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 06:12:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/spacex-launch-japanese-satellite-try-rocket-landing-n569101</link>
      <dc:creator>Mike Wall, Space.com</dc:creator>
      <description>SpaceX officials said the Falcon 9 will be traveling faster when it returns than when the company pulled off an ocean landing last month.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1526456/26809208046_ec24c772aa_k_80e981521e5035c6f16e50ee3493ab10.jpg" medium="image" height="1365" width="2048">
        <media:credit>SpaceX</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Falcon 9 and JCSAT-14 spacecraft vertical on Pad 40, Cape Canaveral, Florida, is seen in this SpaceX photo taken May 5, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/health/cancer/cancer-cells-hijack-body-s-internal-clocks-study-finds-n568981</guid>
      <title>Study Helps Explain How Cancer Kills</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 05 May 2016 23:55:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/health/cancer/cancer-cells-hijack-body-s-internal-clocks-study-finds-n568981</link>
      <dc:creator>Maggie Fox</dc:creator>
      <description>Tumor cells disrupt the body's circadian clocks, interfering with how they make and use sugar and fats for nourishment.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_01/830951/150101-cancer-cells-5p_418b0e4ae584ba9e48e4aeacf8b0430a.jpg" medium="image" height="1832" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Getty Images</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image:  Close up of cancer cells in the cervix.</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain"> Close up of cancer cells. A new study suggests tumor cells hijacks important body clocks.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1526246/160505-human-body-communicating-clocks-yh-0648p_a5560a9e66d926eebd16b8808f71925c.jpg" medium="image" height="2500" width="2401">
        <media:credit>Courtesy of Paolo Sassone-Corsi</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Communicating clocks</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Paolo Sassone-Corsi of the University of California, Irvine believes that tumor cells disrupt the body's circadian clocks, interfering with how they make and use sugar and fats for nourishment.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.globalpost.com/article/6767177/2016/05/04/severe-drought-forces-zimbabwe-sell-wildlife</guid>
      <title>Wild Animals Put on Market to Keep Them From Starving</title>
      <pubDate>Thu, 05 May 2016 07:17:50 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.globalpost.com/article/6767177/2016/05/04/severe-drought-forces-zimbabwe-sell-wildlife</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Cash-strapped ZImbabwe has been battling to reduce its animals whose population is more than twice what the parks can accommodate.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1524886/160505-elephants-0252_f5d36e738b892e3649d03fb20dac2190.jpg" medium="image" height="2196" width="3166">
        <media:credit>PHILIMON BULAWAYO</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: A herd of elephants at Zimbabwe's Hwange National Park</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A herd of elephants visits at a watering hole in Zimbabwe's Hwange National Park on September 29, 2015.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/infected-mosquitoes-can-t-transmit-zika-virus-study-finds-n568261</guid>
      <title>Good Germs Stop Mosquitoes From Spreading Zika</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 23:37:44 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/infected-mosquitoes-can-t-transmit-zika-virus-study-finds-n568261</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Deliberately infecting mosquitoes with a certain type of bacteria stops them from transmitting Zika virus, a new study finds.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_11/1389781/160125-aedes-aegypti-mosquitos-1718_ddc14204976cc1a83d32a304a5ff81b0.jpg" medium="image" height="1651" width="2500">
        <media:credit>James Gathany</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Aedes aegypti mosquito</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">This photo provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows a female Aedes aegypti mosquito in the process of acquiring a blood meal from a human host.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_02/1376166/160114-zika-aedes-aegypti-mosquito-mn-1216_408557b99ee1619e962b167517a4cf07.jpg" medium="image" height="1664" width="2500">
        <media:credit>NELSON ALMEIDA</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: BRAZIL-SENEGAL-SCIENCE-HEALTH-ZIKA-VIRUS</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">A researcher looks at Aedes aegypti mosquitoes kept in a container at a lab of the Institute of Biomedical Sciences of the Sao Paulo University, on Jan. 8, 2016 in Sao Paulo, Brazil. </media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/may-fourth-be-you-fans-celebrate-star-wars-day-n567711</guid>
      <title>'May the Fourth Be With You': Fans Celebrate Star Wars Day</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 13:41:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/may-fourth-be-you-fans-celebrate-star-wars-day-n567711</link>
      <dc:creator>Reuters</dc:creator>
      <description>From dressing up as stormtroopers to hosting movie marathons, fans celebrated Star Wars Day with all things dedicated to the blockbuster franchise.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_51/1339761/star_wars_2_16725d2264bd721ff4d9c28670ff887a.jpg" medium="image" height="1080" width="1920">
        <media:credit>NBC News</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Fans waiting in line outside the theater engage in a friendly duel.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_51/1339761/star_wars_2_16725d2264bd721ff4d9c28670ff887a.jpg" medium="image" height="1080" width="1920">
        <media:credit>NBC News</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Fans waiting in line outside the theater engage in a friendly duel.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://time.com/4316873/london-mayor-election-air-pollution/</guid>
      <title>Why Air Pollution Is Key Issue in Race to Run London</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 13:38:55 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://time.com/4316873/london-mayor-election-air-pollution/</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>Air pollution has emerged as key issue in the race to elect the next London mayor.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media4.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1523531/160504-london-bus-0932_c7a42173e2cb1b8b86bf4ed198496f30.jpg" medium="image" height="3333" width="5000">
        <media:credit>JUSTIN TALLIS</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Electric London bus</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">An electric London bus is pictured during a photocall to promote the world's first purpose-built fully electric double-deck bus in London on March 15, 2016.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.globalpost.com/article/6766975/2016/05/03/one-africas-most-active-volcanoes-showing-new-signs-life</guid>
      <title>One of Africa's Most Active Volcanoes Shows Signs of Life</title>
      <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 12:14:29 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.globalpost.com/article/6766975/2016/05/03/one-africas-most-active-volcanoes-showing-new-signs-life</link>
      <dc:creator />
      <description>The last time Mount Nyiragongo erupted — in 2002 — it killed 147 people and forced 400,000 people to flee the nearby city of Goma.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media3.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1523381/160504-mount-nyiragongo-jsw_26eee8203c2b0cbd65d1539e6da250a7.jpg" medium="image" height="1666" width="2500">
        <media:credit>Mike Korostelev</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">The Lava Lake at Mount Nyiragongo, Democratic Republic of Congo on Aug. 19, 2014. Nyiragongo is one of the most active volcanoes in the world, erupting on average every 30 years, according to programmer Mikhail Korostelev.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/mars-streaky-slopes-may-have-been-carved-out-boiling-water-n567111</guid>
      <title>Mars' Streaky Slopes May Have Been Carved by Boiling Water</title>
      <pubDate>Tue, 03 May 2016 19:58:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/mars-streaky-slopes-may-have-been-carved-out-boiling-water-n567111</link>
      <dc:creator>Charles Q. Choi, Space.com</dc:creator>
      <description>Dark streaks on Martian slopes may have been carved by boiling water, new research suggests.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2015_52/1350516/151222-tech-mars_e16e3bd76cfeb80389c536a4a5070f38.jpg" medium="image" height="512" width="487">
        <media:credit>ISRO</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: Mars</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">Handout picture made available by the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) on 29 September 2014 of regional dust storm activities over Northern Hemisphere of Mars.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/remains-captain-cook-s-ship-likely-rhode-island-coast-n566991</guid>
      <title>Wreckage of 250-Year-Old Ship May Be Off Rhode Island Coast</title>
      <pubDate>Tue, 03 May 2016 17:10:26 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/remains-captain-cook-s-ship-likely-rhode-island-coast-n566991</link>
      <dc:creator>The Associated Press</dc:creator>
      <description>Researchers believe they have found the ship that legendary explorer Captain James Cook used to sail to around the world submerged in Newport Harbor.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1522226/160503-captain-cook-replica-mdl_fdb7fafb9bdb4b02fc336083d6b63809.jpg" medium="image" height="2000" width="1769">
        <media:credit>AP</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">People watch as a replica of the HMB Endeavour leaves Honolulu, Hawaii as it embarked on a four-year, around the world cruise on Nov.15,1999 . The original vessel was commanded by Capt. James Cook in the 1700's when he became the first European to chart Australia's East Coast. It was among a fleet of 13 ships sunk as a blockade in Rhode Island's Newport Harbor during the Revolutionary War in 1778.</media:description>
      </media:content>
      <media:content url="http://media2.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1522226/160503-captain-cook-replica-mdl_fdb7fafb9bdb4b02fc336083d6b63809.jpg" medium="image" height="2000" width="1769">
        <media:credit>AP</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain"></media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">People watch as a replica of the HMB Endeavour leaves Honolulu, Hawaii as it embarked on a four-year, around the world cruise on Nov.15,1999 .</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>

    <item>
      <guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/scientists-eye-3-new-earth-sized-worlds-hunt-e-t-n566281</guid>
      <title>Scientists Eye 3 New Earth-Sized Worlds in Hunt for E.T.</title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2016 21:32:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/scientists-eye-3-new-earth-sized-worlds-hunt-e-t-n566281</link>
      <dc:creator>Associated Press</dc:creator>
      <description>Astronomers searching for life beyond our solar system may need to look no farther than a little, feeble nearby star.</description>
      <media:content url="http://media1.s-nbcnews.com/i/newscms/2016_18/1520791/160502-ultracool-dwarf-star-trappist-1-yh-0602p_1bc895d13e32a55f936c4e26796aa975.jpg" medium="image" height="1795" width="2500">
        <media:credit>European Southern Observatory</media:credit>
        <media:text type="plain">Image: the Sun and the ultracool dwarf star TRAPPIST-1 to scale. The faint star has only 11% of the diameter of the sun and is much redder in colour.</media:text>
        <media:description type="plain">This picture shows the Sun and the ultracool dwarf star TRAPPIST-1 to scale. The faint star has only 11% of the diameter of the sun and is much redder in color.</media:description>
      </media:content>
    </item>
  </channel>
